Well, I think especially with New York, there are two things going on.

There's an out-migration of whites just because of a variety of reasons, the very--the pricey housing market in the New York metropolitan area and just--in the other part of New York state where job opportunities aren't that very strong, there's this movement to the Sun Belt.
And then of course there's a continued immigration to New York, which is the major melting pot of the United States and has been for a long time.
So, you know, this is kind of more of the same.
I think the new ingredient is a decline or the out-migration of the white population there.
Now for Maryland, you know, Maryland is sitting on the cusp of a major metropolitan area that's one of our melting pot places, which is Washington, DC.
So there's this spill-over of the Hispanic and other immigrant groups into the suburbs of Washington, DC, which are in Maryland.
And then there, of course, has been the longtime suburbanization of blacks from DC into the Maryland suburbs.
And this is also going on around Baltimore, too, but I think the juxtaposition within Washington, DC, has a lot to do with Maryland's change.
